docs.lead_paragraph: Party leaders have urged Democratic candidates to talk openly about the health care law’s problems while also offering their own prescriptions to fix them.

headline.main: On Health Act, Democrats Run in Fix-It Mode
headline.print_headline: On Health Act, Democrats Run in Fix-It Mode

docs.abstract: Democratic party leaders, coming to terms with continuing political liability attached to Pres Obama's health care law, are urging Democratic candidates in 2014 midterm elections to talk openly about law's problems and offer solutions; are hoping strategy may help them overcome threats to their ability to hold on to seats in House and Senate.
docs.snippet: Party leaders have urged Democratic candidates to talk openly about the health care law’s problems while also offering their own prescriptions to fix them.

byline.original: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans alike resort to “real people” to get their messages across, sometimes with unexpected consequences.

headline.main: In the Debate Over Health Care, ‘Real People’ Become Human Volleyballs
headline.print_headline: In the Debate Over Health Care, ‘Real People’ Become Human Volleyballs

docs.abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike resort to travails of 'real people' to get their messages across, but method can sometimes backfire; continuing fight over Affordable Care Act has led parties on both sides to fact-check every reference to common citizens and to attack any distortions.
docs.snippet: Democrats and Republicans alike resort to “real people” to get their messages across, sometimes with unexpected consequences.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats held a retreat this week seeking inspiration. But they left as befuddled as ever by an America that arguably likes their issues but not always the party.

headline.main: Democrats Seek to Turn Stand on Issues Into Votes

docs.lead_paragraph: The recent AOL controversy highlights how new 401(k) policies that use lump-sum payments can shortchange employees.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises AOL chief executive Tim Armstrong for reversing decision to start making employer 401(k) contributions in a yearly lump sum; warns growing number of companies are adopting this pernicious cost-saving measure, which comes at the expense of working families and their increasingly insecure retirement plans.
docs.snippet: The recent AOL controversy highlights how new 401(k) policies that use lump-sum payments can shortchange employees.
